_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary For Dorman Brothers, L.L.C., Goodland, Kansas

For further information regarding this plan, please contact:
Michael  Dorman
Dorman Brothers, L.L.C.
19230 County Road 55
Burlington, Colorado 80807
719/346-7970

1.  The Facility Policy
The owners, members, and employees of Dorman Brothers, L.L.C. are committed to the prevention of accidental release of anhydrous ammonia.  If an accidental release should occur, the facility is prepared to work with the local fire department and other agencies to mitigate any release and minimize the impact of the release to people and the enivornment.

2.  Facility Information
This facility was put into operation on October 1, 2002 and the most current safety measures where implemented at that time.  The primary acticity at this facility is the storage of fertilizer for sale to farmers.  Anhydrous ammonia is received, stored, and distributed for direct application.  The maximum quantity stored would be 157,590 pounds of anhydrous ammonia in one fixed-site storage tank.  The ammonia is delivered in by truck.

3.  The Worst-Case Release Scenario and the Althernate Release Scenario
The worst-case release scenario would be the release of the total contents of the storage tank, released as a gas over 10 minutes.  The maximum released would be 131,325 pounds, which represents  85% of the capacity of the tank as limited by design standards.  The distance to the endpoint is 6.9 miles.
The alternate release scenario, based on the most likely potential incident, is a release of 100 lbs. from an overfill.  The distance to endpoint is .2 miles.

4.  The Accidental Release Prevention Program
This facility has jmplemented the provisions of Safety Requirements for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia K-61-1, published by the American National Standards Institute, Inc.  and the standards of the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Adiminstration, 29 CFR 1910.111, Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia.

5.  The Five Year A

ccident History
This facility was put into business on October 1, 2002 and there have been no accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia that have caused any deaths, injured, or caused significant property damage at the facility, or any offsite consequences of a release.

6. The Emergency Action Plan
The Facility has:
-  A written Emergency Action Plan
-  It will provide SARA Title III information to the state and local authorities.
-  Done employee training

7.  Planned Changes to Impove Safety
Safety improvement will be an on-going process at the facility.  Periodic inspections are performed to assess the maintenance of safe conditions.  There are no additional specific anhydrous ammonia safety recommendations for implementation at this time.
